label: Time
info:
### Time Based automation

#### Configuration

This flow contains a `function` node that uses the [suncalc](https://github.com/mourner/suncalc) package and relies on `LATITUDE` and `LONGITUDE` environment variables to specify the geographic coordinates used in determining sunrise and sunset.

> _Geographic coordinates are an example of sensitive personal information that should generally be kept out of flows that might be shared as examples in a forum, pushed to a public source control repository etc._

You can specify environment variables for use in your flows in a number of ways, depending on your preferences and your overall Node-RED configuration. For most "mainstream" scenarios, the simplest way would be to add them to the _~/.node-red/environment_ file in the home directory of the user as whom the Node-RED service is running.

#### Time of Day

The `link out` node named _asdf_ is where time-based automation flows should start, e.g. to adjust lighting, window coverings, HVAC settings etc. for different times of day:

| `msg.payload` | Descrption                                                   |
|---------------|--------------------------------------------------------------|
| `morning`     | Sunrise to _offset_ hours after sunrise                      |
| `midday`      | _Offset_ hours after sunrise to _offset_ hours before sunset |
| `afternoon`   | _Offset_ hours before sunset to sunset                       |
| `evening`     | Sunset to _bedtime_                                          |
| `night`       | _Bedtime_ to sunrise                                         |

_Offset_ is one third of the number of hours between sunrise and sunset.

_Bedtime_ is generated each day to occur at the later of:

- 10:00PM (22:00), plus or minus a randomly generated 30 minute offset
- a randomly generated time, 30 to 60 minutes after sunset

> _Five distinct times of day may seem excessive, but has proven necessary in a number of real-world scenarios. For example, the distinctions between `morning`, `midday` and `afternoon` are invaluable for homes with automated coverings over both East- and West-facing windows. In addition, randomizing `bedtime` can provide a modest degree of "simulated presence" to discourage potential burglars._

#### Theme

In addition to the time-of-day specified by `msg.payload`, as described above, automation flows can also assume that `global.theme` will have been set to a value indicating any special occasions that might be effect:

| `global.theme` | Description         |
|----------------|---------------------|
| `tribal`       | July 1 - 4          |
| `spooky`       | Any day in October  |
| `jolly`        | Any day in December |
| `standard`     | Any other day       |

name: Send to Hue Bridge
info:
# Overview

Send a message to the API (version 2) on a given Hue Bridge.

See <https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/> for details.

_**Note:** the intent is for this subflow to be used for_ every _message sent to a given Hue bridge so as to enforce the rate limits described in the Hue API documentation._

# Configuration

| Environment Variable | Description                         |
|----------------------|-------------------------------------|
| `ADDRESS`            | Bridge's IP address                 |
| `KEY`                | Client access token for the message |

# Input

| Message Property | Description                                                                |
|------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| `msg.topic`      | API URI, e.g. `resource`, `room/0ca8f049-7ac9-4872-8069-4770834e4f11` etc. |
| `msg.payload`    | Request body, if any                                                       |
| `msg.method`     | HTTP request method, e.g. `GET`, `PUT` etc                                 |

# Outputs

If successful, the HTTP response will be sent as a parsed JSON object in `msg.payload` from output 1.

A standard Node-RED error message will be sent on output 2 if the `http request` node throws an exception.

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Send a command to the Hue Bridge API

name: Create Hue Application Key
info:
# Overview

Invoke the Hue Bridge API to create a client access token.

_**N.B.:** Invoke this subflow within 30 seconds of pressing the button on top of the bridge. Watch the debug console output to see the response. If successful, you will see the generated key among the response payload's properties._

See <https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/getting-started/> for details.

# Configuration

| Environment Variable | Description                                    |
|----------------------|------------------------------------------------|
|`ADDRESS`             | Bridge's IP address                            |
| `USERNAME`           | "User name" for which a key is being generated |

# Input

Incoming message triggers HTTP request but is otherwise ignored.

# Output

The HTTP response will be sent as a parsed JSON object. If successful, look for the value of the `msg.payload.success.username` property in the output. That is the string you should use as the access token header in all subsequent Hue Bridge API request messages.

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Invoke the Hue Bridge API for registering a client

name: Set PowerView Scene
info:
# Overview

Use the _Hunter Douglas PowerView_® hub API to activate a given window shade scene.

See <https://motorisation.hde.nl/hd/powerview/general-guides/API/> for details.

# Configuration

The `ADDRESS` environment variable must be configured with the IP address of the hub.

# Input

`msg.payload` containing the id of the scene to activate.

All other input message properties are ignored by the subflow but care should be taken not to pass any through that could affect the behavior of a `http request` node in unintended ways.

# Output

HTTP response from the hub.

# Side Effects

If successful, the window shades will move to the settings defined by the specified scene as configured using the _PowerView_® mobile app.

name: Homebridge Switch
info:
# Background

This subflow implements the Node-RED side of a _Homebridge_ switch using the _mqttthing_ plugin. That plugin uses a confused nomenclature regarding 'get' and 'set' as well as a rather over-engineered repertoire of MQTT messaging that still manages to be missing critical features:

- _mqttthing_ sends a 'set' message each time the user toggles the state of the switch using HomeKit

- _mqttthing_ changes the state of a switch upon receipt of a 'get' message

- _mqttthing_ does **not** send a 'set' message when the switch's state changes due to receipt of a 'get' message.

- rather, _mqttthing_ expects an acknowledging 'get' message after it sends a 'set' message

- _mqttthing_ does _not_ remember the state of a switch across restarts unless Node-RED sends 'get' messages with `retain` set to `true`

- Node-RED does not receive the current state of the switch across restarts unless _mqttthing_ is configured to send 'set' messages with `retain` set to `true`

- when `retain` is `true`, care must be taken not to retrigger any automation or the like at startup (typically using a `filter` node configured to ignore the first message)

It is up to clients like Node-RED flows to make sense of the confused stream of messages that results, including the fact that 'get' and 'set' have the opposite of their conventional meanings. Clients must also act on 'get' messages rather than 'set', meaning that Node-RED must simply take it on faith that _mqttthing_ will act on them, as well.

# Configuration

Note that this subflow assumes a particular naming convention for _mqttthing_ 'get' and 'set topics as configured by _mqttthing_ in the _Homebridge_ config file:

    homebridge/<name>/get
    homebridge/<name>/set

Given that naming convention, each instance of this subflow corresponds to one switch accessory implemented by the _mqttthing_ plugin:

| Environment Variable | Description                                                           |
|----------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------|
| `NAME`               | The second element of the 'get' and 'set' topics                      |
| `RETAIN`             | Value for `msg.retain` when sending 'get' messages to the MQTT broker |

# Input

Boolean value to send as the payload of a `get` message.

# Output

Payload of the most recently received `get` message. May be a retained message if `$RETAIN` is set to `true` for a given instance of this subflow.

# Usage

Assuming that a _Homebridge_ switch accessory is implemented by _mqttthing_ configured with 'get' and 'set' topics as described above, sending a boolean value to the input of a corresponding instance of this subflow will set the state of the matching accessory in _HomeKit_. The subflow will also listen for matching 'set' and 'get' messages, such that messages will be emitted on the subflow output corresponding to the changing state of the _HomeKit_ accessory:

- It listens for both 'get' and 'set' messages matching the topics as described above

- It outputs the topic and payload of each `get` message it receives

- It broadcasts a MQTT message on the 'get' topic for each message it receives from the subflow input

- It rebroadcasts a corresponding 'get' message for each matching 'set' message it receives

The net result (pun intended) is that you can set the _HomeKit_ switch state by injecting a boolean payload into an instance of this subflow and react to asynchronous changes in the switch state by consuming the subflow's output. Depending on how a switch is configured in _mqttthing_ and in the corresponding instance of this subflow, either or both of 'get' and 'set' messages can be retained. This is the only mechanism supported by _mqttthing_ for persisting the state of built in switch accessories across reboots of the _Homebridge_ service.

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Implement Node-RED handling of a toggle switch implemented by the mqttthing plugin for homebridge

name: Monitored Event
info:
Handle MQTT messages for topics that match the value of the `TOPIC` environment variable. Such topics are expected to be of the form `cpu/+/attribute`, for some monitored attribute such as `temperature`, `voltage` etc. The second, wildcard elemnt is expected to be the name of the host that sent the particular message being handled. Such messages are cached in the context of a function node in this subflow as an object whose keys are the host names. The value for each host is an object whose key is the name of the attribute and whose value is the value for the most recently received message for that attribute from that host. For example, assuming that `${TOPIC}` is configured to be `cpu/+/temperature`, the following sequence of messages: cpu/host1/temperature : 31 cpu/host2/temperature : 55 cpu/host3/temperature : 49 would result in the cached state becoming: { host1: { temperature: 31 }, host2: { temperature: 55 }, host5: { temperature: 49 } } If a subsequent message were received: cpu/host2/temperature : 56 the cached state would be updated to: { host1: { temperature: 31 }, host2: { temperature: 56 }, host5: { temperature: 49 } } ...and so on. The subflow has two outputs: 1. A HTML `` representing the cached state for all hosts after updating it upon the receipt of each message, presumably for display using a dashboard _template_ node. 2. The raw event for subsequent processing, e.g. taking action if some CPU overheats. The `
` emitted for the updated state descibed above would be something like (_extra whitespace and comments inserted here for readability_):
host temperature
host1 31C
host2 56C
host3 49C
As noted in the HTML comments, the formatting of the `` can be tweaked by two additional environment variables: - The value of `UNIT`, which defaults to the empty string, will be appended to each value in the second column. - The first, `
`, row will only be included in the HTML output if the value of `HEADER` is `true`.

name: Hue to MQTT
info:
# Overview

This subflow:

- Caches the state of Philips Hue devices in flow context using the response  to an invocation of the `/resource` end-point of the [Philips Hue Bridge V2 API](https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/api-reference/#resource).

- Outputs a stream of individual event messages as the cached devices' states change by subscribing to [SSE messages](https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/core-concepts/#events).

Each event message will have appropriate MQTT topic, QoS and retain properties set in addition to the payload sent by the Hue bridge.

_**Note:** the `switch` node named "filter resources" in this subflow is used to restrict the number of messages processed at startup to only those types of resources likely to be of interest to Node-RED based automation. This means that over time you will receive SSE messages for resources whose state did not appear in the initial output from this subflow. If you wish for 100% consistency across all resource types, remove the "filter resources" node from between the two `split` nodes, but be warned that will cause a much larger volume of MQTT messaging each time your flows are restarted._

# Dependency

[node-red-contrib-sse-client](https://flows.nodered.org/node/node-red-contrib-sse-client)

# Configuration

A separate subflow instance can be created for each Hue bridge by using the following configuration variables:

| Environment Variable | Description                                                             |
|----------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| `ADDRESS`            | IP address of the Hue bridge                                            |
| `KEY`                | "Client key" for the Hue bridge API<sup>*</sup>                         |
| `TOPIC`              | String to prepend to each `msg.topic` in the output, as described below |

<sup>*</sup>_See <https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/getting-started/> for details. Use the_ Create Hue Access Token _subflow to obtain such a key._

# Input

Response from a successful call to the `/resource` end-point of the [Philips Hue Bridge V2 API](https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/api-reference/#resource) in `msg.payload`.

# Output

An ongoing sequence of message objects representing the state of each device as reported by [SSE](https://developers.meethue.com/develop/hue-api-v2/core-concepts/#events). Each message will have the following properties set:

| Property | Value |
|-|-|
| `msg.topic` | `${TOPIC}/<type>/<id>` where `<type>` and `<id>` are the identifiers for a given "resource" as reported by the Hue bridge API. |
| `msg.qos` | 2 |
| `msg.retain` | `true` |
| `msg.payload` | The current state of the given "resource"<sup>**</sup> |

<sup>**</sup>_Note that each output message will contain a combined set of properties for each "resource" received across multiple API responses and SSE messages. This mitigates one of the many issues with the design of the Philips Hue API. The cached state is maintained in flow context at runtime and as retained MQTT messages across reboots._

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Forward SSE events arising from the Hue Bridge API to MQTT

meta.author: parasaurolophus <apps@rader.us>
meta.desc: Parse the response to a "/resource" request from the Hue API V2

meta.desc: Count the number of MQTT messages received on a specfied topic
